comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The cast-iron awnings on both sides of Brickfield Hill / George Street are amazing in this photo. @ PhMC - Anthony Hordern's New Palace Emporium (1905) was not yet built at the time of this picture (except for an older, smaller store further down the street - see note), but it shows up as "before and after" shots here - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2667018244/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: This is one of several pictures of George Street where the tram pylons and wires are apparent, but no trams.  Which might help date the photos to December 1899, just before trams started on this route.  Unless the trams were on strike . . .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
32162360@N00
comment._content: The poster for the "Grand Commonwealth Fair" occurs in several pictures of George Street, implying they must be contemporary to the event at the Town Hall in November / December 1899. The trams on this part of George St started in December 1899. See other pictures - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2712341239/ and www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3041763769/

comment.author: 29029178@N03
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Sydney's older buildings and structures. , and we'd love to have this added to the group!
